content: This is how monopolies are built. The large growers can afford the requirements and most often put the costs into the price of the product. Small growers are the safer foods. when you know who grew your food and deal with them face-to-face, they will treat the deal on a personal level and provide the best produce.

content: quote: Originally posted by soscorpio: This is how monopolies are built. It certainly helps... quote: Originally posted by soscorpio: Small growers are the safer foods. when you know who grew your food and deal with them face-to-face, they will treat the deal on a personal level and provide the best produce. This is not necessarily true. The last restaurant I worked in made apoint of trying to buy from small local farms and vendors, will the remainder bought from one of the big restaurant supply companies. The big vendor was as consistent as clockwork - same quality, same schedule, every time. Not great, mind you, but consistent. The small vendors were all over the place - some were great quality and excellent service. Others tried to sell us substandard product, whenever they got around to delivering it. The bad ones stayed in business - other restaurants were not so diligent in inspecting their meat and produce, or else chose the lower price vendor to maximize their profits. My point is that small companies are quite varied, and even the bad ones (the ones who will happily sell you a case of rotting potatoes as good) can stay in business for decades if no one is calling on them on their quality. Since restaurants and individual buyers lack the ability to check certain things, professional inspections are at least occasionally necessary. The trick is that they cannot be so onerus that small companies cannot stay afloat.
quote: Originally posted by soscorpio: This is how monopolies are built.
reply: It certainly helps... quote: Originally posted by soscorpio: Small growers are the safer foods. when you know who grew your food and deal with them face-to-face, they will treat the deal on a personal level and provide the best produce. The bad ones stayed in business - other restaurants were not so diligent in inspecting their meat and produce, or else chose the lower price vendor to maximize their profits. My point is that small companies are quite varied, and even the bad ones (the ones who will happily sell you a case of rotting potatoes as good) can stay in business for decades if no one is calling on them on their quality. Since restaurants and individual buyers lack the ability to check certain things, professional inspections are at least occasionally necessary. The trick is that they cannot be so onerus that small companies cannot stay afloat.

What ever happened to caveat emptor Buyer beware? do we need more government telling us how to live free? title: HR875?

content: quote: Originally posted by Duster6: I guess these politicians sit in their offices everyday and think," How can I screw the American public today". It's the politics of fear and mass hysteria. Congress only responds to that. Ever notice how stories about someone being poisoned by food gets wide-spread and detailed play in the news? It's nothing new as food has probably killed about as many people over the centuries as any other cause, so why is it an issue now? Because someone, somewhere, has an agenda and they know fully well that if they can create a panic, government must respond. While y'all are right to be concerned about this pending legislation, are you also aware of the already existing laws which, when they become mandatory in 2010, will require you to number your cows and pigs individually and keep track of where they went? Poultry will have to have tracking numbers by lot. And, you'll be subject to government inspection of your records. Why? Fear of "mad cow disease" was the motivation behind that law. How many times, and in how many ways, will we let ourselves be driven with fear to support someone elses agenda? Automobile safety; smoking; health care; gun rights; political parties and now food. The list goes on and on and too many people fall for it every time.
quote: Originally posted by Duster6: I guess these politicians sit in their offices everyday and think," How can I screw the American public today".

Because someone, somewhere, has an agenda and they know fully well that if they can create a panic, government must respond. While y'all are right to be concerned about this pending legislation, are you also aware of the already existing laws which, when they become mandatory in 2010, will require you to number your cows and pigs individually and keep track of where they went? How many times, and in how many ways, will we let ourselves be driven with fear to support someone elses agenda? Automobile safety; smoking; health care; gun rights; political parties and now food. The list goes on and on and too many people fall for it every time.

content: A Great History Lesson For All Of Us An economics professor at Texas Tech said he had never failed a single student before but had, once, failed an entire class. The majority of the class had insisted that socialism was a better system as no one would be poor and no one would be rich, a great equalizer. The professor then said ok, we will have an experiment in this class on socialism. All grades would be averaged and everyone would receive the same grade so no one would fail and no one would receive an A. After the first test the grades were averaged and everyone got a B. The students who studied hard were upset and the students who studied little were happy. But, as the second test rolled around, the students who studied little had studied even less and the ones who studied hard decided they wanted a free ride too; so they studied little. The second Test average was a D! No one was happy. When the 3rd test rolled around the average was an F. The scores never increased as bickering, blame, name calling all resulted in hard feelings and no one would study for anyone else. All failed to their great surprise and the professor told them that socialism would ultimately fail because the harder to succeed the greater the reward but when a government takes all the reward away; no one will try or succeed.

content: I've been thinking.... I wonder if this will be my last year to legally have a personal garden or shop the farmers markets? I was looking at the small tractors and tillers at Home Depot and thought that they will be nothing more than un-needed junk if this law is passed and pushed to it's potential limits. I guess I would have to move to Mexico with all the others who would want to continue having their own gardens. Canada is out of the question because it is too damn cold up there!

The bad ones stayed in business - other restaurants were not so diligent in inspecting their meat and produce, or else chose the lower price vendor to maximize their profits. My point is that small companies are quite varied, and even the bad ones (the ones who will happily sell you a case of rotting potatoes as good) can stay in business for decades if no one is calling on them on their quality. Since restaurants and individual buyers lack the ability to check certain things, professional inspections are at least occasionally necessary. The trick is that they cannot be so onerus that small companies cannot stay afloat.
title: HR875?

title: HR875?

content: quote: Originally posted by Duster6: I guess these politicians sit in their offices everyday and think," How can I screw the American public today". It's the politics of fear and mass hysteria. Congress only responds to that. Ever notice how stories about someone being poisoned by food gets wide-spread and detailed play in the news? It's nothing new as food has probably killed about as many people over the centuries as any other cause, so why is it an issue now? Because someone, somewhere, has an agenda and they know fully well that if they can create a panic, government must respond. While y'all are right to be concerned about this pending legislation, are you also aware of the already existing laws which, when they become mandatory in 2010, will require you to number your cows and pigs individually and keep track of where they went? Poultry will have to have tracking numbers by lot. And, you'll be subject to government inspection of your records. Why? Fear of "mad cow disease" was the motivation behind that law. How many times, and in how many ways, will we let ourselves be driven with fear to support someone elses agenda? Automobile safety; smoking; health care; gun rights; political parties and now food. The list goes on and on and too many people fall for it every time.

content: A Great History Lesson For All Of Us An economics professor at Texas Tech said he had never failed a single student before but had, once, failed an entire class. The majority of the class had insisted that socialism was a better system as no one would be poor and no one would be rich, a great equalizer. The professor then said ok, we will have an experiment in this class on socialism. All grades would be averaged and everyone would receive the same grade so no one would fail and no one would receive an A. After the first test the grades were averaged and everyone got a B. The students who studied hard were upset and the students who studied little were happy. But, as the second test rolled around, the students who studied little had studied even less and the ones who studied hard decided they wanted a free ride too; so they studied little. The second Test average was a D! No one was happy. When the 3rd test rolled around the average was an F. The scores never increased as bickering, blame, name calling all resulted in hard feelings and no one would study for anyone else. All failed to their great surprise and the professor told them that socialism would ultimately fail because the harder to succeed the greater the reward but when a government takes all the reward away; no one will try or succeed.
